def lang_pie(xx_lang):
    xx = sorted(xx_lang.items(), key=lambda t: t[1], reverse=True)
    res = xx[:5]
    c = 0
    for x  in xx[6:]:
        c += x[1]
    res.append(('others',c))
    return res
    
ca_lang_pie = lang_pie(ca_lang)
de_lang_pie = lang_pie(de_lang)
fr_lang_pie = lang_pie(fr_lang)
gb_lang_pie = lang_pie(gb_lang)
ind_lang_pie = lang_pie(ind_lang)
jp_lang_pie = lang_pie(jp_lang)
kr_lang_pie = lang_pie(kr_lang)
mx_lang_pie = lang_pie(mx_lang)
ru_lang_pie = lang_pie(ru_lang)
us_lang_pie = lang_pie(us_lang)

def pie(xx_lang_pie, title):
    size = []
    labels = []
    for x in xx_lang_pie:
        size.append(x[1])
        labels.append(x[0])
    fig, axs = plt.subplots()
    axs.set_title(title)
    axs.pie(size, labels=labels)

pie(ca_lang_pie,'CANADA')
pie(de_lang_pie,'GERMANY')
pie(fr_lang_pie,'FRANCE')
pie(gb_lang_pie,'GREAT BRITAIN')
pie(ind_lang_pie,'INDIA')
pie(jp_lang_pie,'JAPAN')
pie(kr_lang_pie,'SOUTH KOREA')
pie(mx_lang_pie,'MEXICO')
pie(ru_lang_pie,'RUSSIA')
pie(us_lang_pie,'USA')

source.99403ba9: In the first part of this notebook, we will use [langdetect](https://pypi.org/project/langdetect/), a Python library from Google for text language recognition. Thus, we hope to have a good overview of the languages of trending videos on Youtube. So, we will try to detect these languages from the titles and descriptions of videos. Of course, it is not perfect, titles and descriptions can be in different languages, and I guess there are also cases where the language of the video differs from what is written. Moreover, a video can be multilingual. We will only return the main language. Speech recognition would be more accurate, but it implies to download the videos from the dataset, instead of only using the dataset, and I don't think kaggle limitations in time and ressources would allow that :-P

source.fee8e496:
By looking at the three main languages of each country, we can have some interesting information:
* English-speaking countries have English as first language (even India)
* Non-english speaking countries have their national language first, and English in second
* Canada is a bilingual country. Its second language, French, is second.
* India is a multilingual country. Tamil has a slightly better score than Hindi.
* 3rd language can reflects the existence of a big community inside the country, like Turkish for Germany, Arabic for France or Vietnamese for Korea.
* In the USA, English is alone. Despite a big number of Spanish-speaking inhabitants, Spanish is second with only 61 hints.
source.a68afe8d: With these pie charts, we can see that the first language of each country is strongly dominant. Only Germany and France leave more than a quarter of the top trending videos for other languages than their first one. In India, the linguistic diversity is totally drowned by the english language, it seems that, sadly, there is no much place on Youtube for the local languages. USA is the less open country to other languages, which is also quite a (bad) surprise for a country with a strong immigration.
